Anaerobic respiration is a relatively inefficient process, a large input of substrate being required for a small return of energy, the end-product (when organic) retaining unutilised energy. When oxygen is available as the oxidising agent, a much more efficient process ensues from the pyruvic acid formed by glycolysis. More complex systems of enzymes are required (e.g. cytochromes, oxidases), these being located in the mitochondria of the cell. A number of organic acids (e.g. citric, fumic, malic, succinic) are formed which are intermediates of other metabolic reactions, e.g. the synthesis of amino acids. The sequence of reactions is known as the modified Krebs Tricarboxylic Acid or Citric Acid cycle, and has an over-all result, starting from glucose through glycolysis, which may be expressed as:-

glucose + 28 phosphate + 6O₂ — 6CO₂, + 44H₂0 + 38 ATP.

See also cytochrome, fermentation, oxidation-reduction, phosphorylation, photosynthesis.

of respiration, the ratio of the amount of carbon dioxide evolved to the amount of oxygen consumed, unity attained when sugars are the substrates, less than unity when the substrate is a fat, and greater than unity when the substrate is an organic acid formed during the citric acid cycle.
as in restiacea, restio, a rope or cord.
turned completely around so as to appear upside down. From L. resupinere, to bend back.
as in retacious, retiform, a net (or network).
the diminutive of rete.
forming a network, as the venation of many dicots.

a network of fine threads or lines. Of certain optical instruments (e.g. a microscope) a net- or grate-work of finely engraved lines on glass inserted in the optical system as a means, e.g. of measurement.
as in retrogressive, backwards (hence reverting to the primitive state; degenerating).

of stems for the extraction of fibres (e.g. of jute, flax, hemp), the controlled partial separation of the bark and fibres of the phloem from the surrounding softer tissues, through exposure to the atmosphere or steeping (in water) and exposure to the fermentative action of certain soil-dwelling bacteria.
turned or directed backwardly. Also retroverse. From L. retrorsum, backwards.
of an apex when obtuse and with a broad, shallow, central notch. from L. retusus, blunted.
turning back to an ancestral form. Returning from the domesticated (cultivated) state to the wild.
of a lamina when its margin is directly downwardly and towards the central line (e.g. mid-rib) of the undersurface. Cf. involute. From L. revolvere, to roll back.
as in rhabdoid, a rod.
a spine. See under rachi.
as in rhagodia, a berry. From Gk. rhax, a grape.
as in rhamnus, a tuft of branches. From Celtic ram.
as in rhamphoid, a curved beak.
as in rhaphiophylla, a needle.
as in rheoplankton, a flow or stream (hence plankton of streams and watercourses).
responsive to the stimulus of a current (of water, air, electricity, etc.).
as in rhinanthus, a snout. From Gk. rhise, nose.
as in rhipidate, rhipidium, a fan.
see undr cyme.
as in riphogonium, a flexible branch (of willow).
as in rhizomorphous, mycorrhiza, a root.
the absorbing and anchoring filamentous structure of non-vascular plants, especially of the bryophytes.
developing rhizomes.

a main shoot when more or less horizontal, subterranean or prostrate, developing adventitious roots and scale-leaves within the axils of which are buds. Usually laterally branching by the determinate nature of a segment when terminated by a bud which develops to an aerial leaf, frond, or leaf-sheath, or a floral axis, further growth of the rhizome being continued from an axillary bud. Sometimes wiry and creeping, as of some grasses (e.g. couch) and ferns, sometimes fleshy and serving mainly for storage (e.g. the sources of asparagus (Asparagus officinalis), ginger (Zingiber officinale), licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra) and the rhubarbs (Rheum officinale, R. rhapontieum). Each segment with an intact growth point is capable under suitable conditions of growth as an independent individual.

of a pteridophyte (the fossil lepidodendrids and the extant Isoetes), the basal part of the shoot bearing branched roots. 

Of a fungus, a cord or thread-like mass of hyphae, sometimes (e.g. the tree-parasitic Armillaria mellea) extending for several metres.
of a lycopod, a part of a stem from which develop temporary adventitious roots.
the part of a soil immediately associated with a root-system.
as in rhodanthe, rhododendron, rose.
of a lamina when quadrilateral, with obtuse lateral angles and acute basal and apical angles.
of a three-dimensional structure when rhombic in several planes.

as in rhynchosia, macrorrhyncha, a snout or beak. In such compounded words as macrorrhyncha (macro (r)-rhyncha), microrrhiza, glycyrrhiza, xanthorrhoea, derived from the Greek, it is customary to place an 'r' before the 'rh'.
as in rhytisperma, rhytidophyllum, a wrinkle (hence the seed and leaf respectively with a wrinkled appearance).
the outer bark.
a costa (q.v.). Of venation, a vein when major or prominent (e.g. a mid-rib).

a globular organelle of cytoplasm composed essentially of ribonucleic acid (rRNA), the major site of protein synthesis. Formerly microsome but separated on the basis of its content. Similar sphaerical bodies with an undetermined function are sphaerosomes.
as in ricinocarpus, of the Castor Oil Plant Ricinus communis, the generic name derived from L. ricinus, a tick in reference to the tick-like seeds.
a valley formed by the subsidence of land between two approximately parallel faults, e.g. the gulfs of Spencer's and St. Vincent's of South Australia.
stiff; unbending; not pliable.
as in rimose, rimulose, a cleft or fissure.
a firm, leathery outer wall (exocarp) of certain baccate fruits, e.g. the hesperidium of citrus, the pepo of cucurbits, the berry of banana.
gaping. Of a labiate corolla when the upper lip is widely arched.
of hardwoods, with vessels tending to be arranged in concentric rings.
of, or located on, the banks of rivers. From L. ripa, a river-bank.
as in rivose, rivulose, a stream and streamlet respectively (hence marked by winding lines or channels to greater or lesser degree).
of a watercourse.

the region in the immediate vicinity of a river. Also riverine. The low-lying, flat lands subject to flooding from the Murray River system support a Riverain forest in which the Red Gum Eucalyptus camaldulensis is dominant.
of sturdy habit; robust.
in general, mineral matter, not necessarily hard or compact, which forms portion of the earth's crust and from which soil may be derived. Usually of igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic origin.
of progeny, a member displaying features not normal to the average. Rogueing: the removal (culling) of a rogue.

the absorbing, anchoring, storing, usually subterranean organ of a vascular plant continuous with the stem, frequently branched with outgrowths of the epidermis, root-hairs, in a region (piliferous layer) close to the growth tip which provide the major absorbing surface, and a root-cap at the tip constantly replaced by actively-dividing meristem during its function of protection against abrasion. See also adventitious root, aerial root, buttress-root, cortex, endodermis, epidermis, knee, passage cell, pericycle, plerome, prop-root, primary root, transpiration-cohesion-tension, vascular system.
as in chaemarops, a bush.
of the rose Rosa (Rosaceae).
a cluster radiating from a common source, e.g. a cluster of radical Leaves.
as in rostellate, rostrate, a beak (hence with a small beak- (rostellum-) and beak- (rostrum-) like projection).
arranged in a rosette.
rounded, almost orbicular.
as in rubens, rubrus, rubicundus, rubidus, red.
reddish.
rust-coloured; brownish-red.
as in rubioides, of Rubia (Rubiaceae).
growing on rubbish dumps or waste lands. From L. rudus, debris.
red; reddish-brown. From L. rufus, reddish.
as in rugose, a wrinkle; a crease.
with a wrinkled surface. Marked by irregular raised or depressed lines. Rugulose: the diminutive condition.
in general, appearing as though chewed. Of endosperm when its surface is marked irregularly by distinct depressions.
in general, sharply incised. Of a lamina when divided into a number of triangular lobes which have their points directed towards the base, as in the Dandelion Taraxacum officinale.

a slender, prostrate and creeping stem developing adventitious roots, and leaves, from nodes. On death of the segment of a runner on either side of the node, the developed structure has the potential for establishment as an independent plant. Usually taken as an equivalent of stolon.
of rainfall, that part discharged or drained from the land.
a rock or cliff.
growing among rocks.
inhabiting the country (rus).
as in ruscifolia, of Ruscus (Liliaceae).
somewhat red.
of disease, especially of cereals, one caused by a member of Uredinales (Basidiomycetes), e.g. the several species of Puccinia.
of the country; rural.
becoming reddish in colour.
sensu lato (in a broad sense); sp.: a species; spp.: species, in plurality; (et) seqq.: (et) sequentes (and the following): ssp.: subspecies; s.str.: sensu stricto (in a narrow sense).
as in sabuline, gravel or sand.
forming a sac or sacs, e.g. of a sepal or petal when dilated on one side to form one or more depressions. Also gibbous.
as in saccharide, a sugar. From Gk. sakchar.
as in sagittate, sagittifolia, an arrow.
of a section when in a central longitudinal plane.
of a lamina when its apex is acute and, like an arrow-head, the base is divided to two acute lobes which point downwardly.
as in saliferous, salt.
as in salicifolia, the willow Salix (Salicaceae).
of the wood of willow. From sali-(l)ignus.
a non-alkaline soil with sufficient accumulation of salts (e.g. of sodium, calcium, magnesium, potassium) to be toxic to plants other than halophytes.
as in salmoniphloia, a salmon (hence with salmon-coloured, or yellowish-pink, bark).
as in salpiglossis, a tube.

relative to the halophilous members of Chenopodiaceae known for their value as drought-resisting fodder plants, e.g. the saltbushes and the bluebushes (q.v.). The name is taken from Salsola a cosmopolitan genus of the same family, also halophilous but known in this country far less for useful members, e.g. Salsola kali is a declared weed, the widespread 'roly-poly'.
as in salsuginous, saline; brackish (hence growing in soils high in salt content).

in a general sense, sodium chloride but extended to (in plant physiology) a soluble form of a mineral nutrient, e.g. potassium nitrate, calcium phosphate, magnesium sulphate etc. Chemically, the product of an acid and a base reactant in equivalent proportions, particularly when these substances are strongly ionising. When one is weak, an acidic or basic salt may form by hydrolysis.

a community of, or a member of, Atriplex, Enchylaena, and Rhagodia in the inland and arid interior of the continent, with long-established recognition as drought-resisting fodder-plants (although small shrubs). A community of soils with clay texture, often saline (e.g. Atriplex vesicaria). See also bluebush.

a shallow, usually rounded, depression of land occurring in arid and semi-arid regions, in which the underlying rock is impregnated with salt brought to the surface by capillary action during the dry season. Many of the salt 'lakes' of inland Australia (e.g. Lakes Frome, Eyre, Cowell, Moore etc.) are of this nature. Lake Eyre of about 180,000 sq. miles has claim of being the driest part of the continent; its average annual rainfall is from four to six inches.
wooded. saltuensis: belonging to, or originating from, forest.
health-promoting; salubrious (e.g. from some principle contained by a plant).

a dry, indehiscent, one or few-seeded fruit (an achenial fruit) with the pericarp extended as a winged margin of aid in dissemination by wind. Sometimes multiple when derived from a bi- or tri- carpellate ovary, then the individual unit known as a mericarp.
resembling a samara.

a halophilous succulent characteristic of salt-marsh communities either estuarine or littoral. A member of such a community when of the amily Chenopodiaceae, viz. Arthrocnemum, Pachycornia, Salicornia.
of soil, the fraction in which the particle size varies from 1.00 to 0.05 mm. See also texture.
blood-red.
of a cell, an aqueous solution of inorganic salts, sugars, amino acids and other solutes stored in a vacuole.

the growth stage of an erect tree beginning with the shedding of branches from the base of the crown as the bole increases in height, commencing on average after three or four years of active growth of the main stem.
as in saponaceous, saponin, soap.

a glycoside (q.v.) which forms soapy foams and stable emulsions with oils, fats and resins, hence of value as an emulsifying agent and surfactant. Occurs generally in leaves, roots and seeds, e.g. of Black Bean Castanospermum australe (seed), Whitewood Atalaya hemiglauca and Red Ash Alphitonia excelsa (foliage).
as in saprobic, saprophilous, rotted; decaying.
causing, or resulting from, decay.
a plant dependent for nutrition on the reduction of organic matter (i.e. decay and putrefaction) from the dead tissues or products of other organisms. Also saprobe.

of secondary xylem while still functional for water-transport before its conversion to an inner zone, heartwood, i.e. before blockage of cells by such products as gums, resins, tannins, and the desiccation of parenchyma occurs. The outer, often lighter-coloured, zone of wood as distinct from heartwood.
package.
as in sarcostemma, of flesh; fleshy. From Gk. sarx.
a pike.
a twig.
forming long runners.
sown; cultivated.

of a process in respect to a factor when an increase in the intensity of the factor no longer causes an increase in the rate of the process. Of a chemical compound when undergoing with difficulty reactions adding new atoms to atoms or groups of atoms already present, although readily responsive to reactions replacing or substituting those atoms already present.

a community, dominated by perennial xeromorphic grasses with a scattering of shrubs and trees, of occurence in tropical and sub-tropical regions with a summer rainfall and a definite dry season. Savannah Woodland: a woodland (q.v.) open and dominated by scattered trees, with a poor development of shrubs but with a continuous lower stratum or grasses. A community of both tropical and temperate regions. Tree (or shrub) savannah: a savannah with scattered trees (or tall shrubs or small trees), occurring singly or in small stands. From Spanish sabana. See also steppe.
as in saxatile, saxicolous, a rock; a large stone.
rough, scabriuscul(us), the diminutive: scaberim(us), the superlative.
of a surface when roughened by minute protuberances. Also scabrate.
as in scaevola, on the left side (of the genus alluding to the unilateral, fan-like corolla).
as in scalariform, a ladder.
of a quantity measurable in a single dimension, e.g. of weight, volume, length.
marked by a series of transverse bars or lines, as certain tracheids and vessels when marked by an arrangement of pits.
of land when eroded by wind, the surface soil being completely removed to leave bare patches in a vegetation.
climbing, e.g. by tendrils.
the floral stem or peduncle of an otherwise stem-less plant (e.g. a rosette plant) bearing one or more flowers and (usually) scales or bracts. Scapigerous, scapose: bearing or producing a scape.

of seed, the breaking of dormancy by removal, through physical or chemical means, of a barrier resistant to the permeation of water (e.g. a barrier formed by a covering of the seed-coat with a fatty substance).
of a structure when dry, thin, and membranous, usually not green.
or the general sense, see escarpment.
a 'royal staff' or sceptre. Sceptriferous: bearing a sceptre-like structure.
as in schistorrhiza, cloven; split.
a rock with a tendency to form flakes by cleavage, e.g. mica.
as in schizolepis, to cleave; to split.
a fruit when dry and formed from a syncarpous ovary, with the carpels separating as one-seeded mericarps but usually not dehiscing.
formed by or originating from, a cleavage. Of a cavity within a tissue when formed by the retraction or spatial movement of cells.
of a cavity within a tissue when formed by a combination of retraction and lysis (dissolution) of cells.
a plant when reproducing by the simple 'splitting apart' of a cell (binary fission); a bacterium or blue-green alga, a procaryote.
of a graft (q.v.), the part (usually a shoot or bud) from a source external to the grafting (i.e. introduced to the stock).
as in sciophilous, shade. From Gk. skia.
a plant adapted to conditions of constant shade, i.e. a sciophilous plant.
cleavable.
splitting as though cut into thin sheets.
as in scleranthus, sclereid, sclerophyll, hard.
a unit of sclerenchyma, a cell with a lignified, thick and pitted wall and usually devoid of, or with very little, protoplast.
a supporting tissue of cells with thickened walls.
of parenchyma, a change to sclerenchyma by a development of secondary-thickened walls, often with a desiccation of protoplasts and a lignification.
a closed community dominated by evergreen sclerophyllous trees (e.g. eucalypts) with flat-topped crowns and trunks equal to or longer than the depths of the crowns.
hard leaved, i.e. with leaves coriaceous and evergreen, usually with an abundance of sclerenchyma, the feature of a sclerophyte.
a plant not succulent in its vegetative parts, its leaves coriaceous, often with sunken stomates and a thick cuticle.
Of a plant cell when hardened by a deposition of lignin.
(plural sclerotia) of a fungus, a mass of hyphae forming a hardened, usually rounded structure; a resting-body, e.g. the stone-like 'Blackfellow's Bread' formed by Polyporus myllitae.
as in scobinate, a file (hence with a rasp-like surface).
as in scolecarpus, a worm (hence with worm-like fruit).
as in scolymus, a thorn (hence thorny or spiny).
as in scopate, scopiform, scoparium, a broom or brush. scopula, a small brush.
as in microscope, basiscopic, microscopy, an instrument for, an aspect of, and the process or technique of (respectively) viewing. From Gk. skopos, a watcher.
as in scorpioid, a scorpion (hence coiled like the tail of a scorpion. See also under cyme).
as in scotophilous, darkness.
a climbing or semi-climbing plant without special means of securing a hold to a support.
as in (the diminutive) scrobiculate, a ditch (hence marked by minute pits or depressions).

a community dominated by evergreen tall shrubs or small, low-branching trees, frequently forming entangled dense covers, e.g. the mallee, mulga, brigalow scrubs of the mainland, the 'horizontal scrub' of south-west Tasmania formed by entangled, impenetrable Anodopetalum biglandulosum (Cunoniaceae).
the hairs of an epidermis when stellate and connected to form scale-like plates. Scurfy: with an abundance of scurf (or scales) to appear silvery.
as in scutigerous, scutiform, a shield. Scutat(us): bearing a shield.
as in scutelligerous, scutelliform, a small shield.
of the embryo of many monocots, a shield-shaped part of the cotyledon which absorbs nutrient stored in the seed but outside the embryo.
as in scyphoid, scyphiform, a cup.
as in scytopetalus, of leather; leathery.

an herbaceous monocot of an estuarine community occurring submerged at varying depth. Prominent in waters of the coast are Zostera (shallow flats with mud-bottom), Halophyla (deep muddy water), Posidonia (sandy slopes) and Ruppia (semi-saline waters).
of growth when incrementing primary growth through the activity of a vascular cambium and (often) a phellogen. See cambium.
a cell occurring singly, or in a series to form a group, gland, duct or tube, within a tissue functioning for the storage of specific secretions (e.g. nectar, latex, resin, oil).
cut into parts. From L. secare, to cut.
of parts (e.g. pinnae) or organs (e.g. flowers) when arising from one side of an axis, i.e. unilaterally. From L. secundus, following.
of soil when developed directly from the underlying rock.
of rock when formed from earlier rocks and deposited as a sediment (usually in layers) under, or from solution in, water. e.g. limestone, sandstone, shale.

the settling out of suspension of solid particles in a liquid by gravitational force, to produce a more or less two-phased system, an upper relatively clear effluent and a lower relatively solid sludge (or sediment).

a matured ovule within which develops an embryo. The integument of the ovule becomes the testa (seed coat), the second fertilisation concurrent with the formation of the zygote produces an endosperm of nutritive value to the embryo, and in some cases, a development from the integument or nucellus produces an accessory nutrient tissue, perisperm. See also dormancy, scarification, stratification, fruit, dissemination.
of alleles (q.v.), their separation (at meiosis) so that gametes ultimately formed carry one or other of the alternative factors.
as in segetalis, segetum, a cornfield; a crop.
a cutting; a part (hence segmentation, the division of an object into parts or segments).
slow; late.
as in seismonastic, a shaking; a shock.
responsive to a stimulus created by a vibration.
of evolution, see natural selection.
as in selenotropic, the moon.
containing or yielding the mineral selenium.
turning in the direction of the moon.
the union of gametes contributed by the one individual, the genetic effect being an increase in homozygosity.
self fertilisation, e.g. when induced from normally cross-fertilising individuals by artificial means. Self: the progeny or product of selfing.

of soil when forming its own much after rain by the breaking-up of the surface, when redried, to fragments less than half an inch in diameter. Usually associated with a presence of free lime in the surface layer.
the transference of pollen from an anther to the stigma of the same flower, not necessarily implying a successful self-fertilisation, e.g. self sterility may be a barrier.

the incompatability of male and female gametes contributed by the individual (e.g. a self-pollinated flower). In angiosperms, the incompatability concerning the pollen-grain and stigma, the pollen tube and style, or the male gamete and the egg-cell within the embryo sac.
as in brachysema, a standard.
seed; race; progeny.
half.
of a membrane when selectively permeable to water and certain of its solutes (in solution) but not other solutes.
at all times; always (hence sempervirens, evergreen).
as in senecifolia, of Senecio (Compositae). From L. senex, an old man.
the process of ageing; physiological decline.
rough; thorny.
as in seorsifolia, scattered; apart from.
the leaf-like unit of a calyx, sometimes petaloid or reduced to a lobe, tooth, scale, bristle or border. Sepaloid: resembling a sepal. Derived from L. separatio, a separation.
as in sepicolous, sepiarius, a hedge (hence forming, or growing as, a hedge).
putrefaction. Septicos: putrefactive.
divided by partitions (septa), each partition a septum. From L. septum. Septal: of a septum.
as in septifoliolate, seven, and seven times respectively. septeni: seven each; septimus: the seventh.
northern.
of dehiscence when along the septa common to adjacent carpels.
belonging to a burial place; sepulchral.
see chelate.
of ecology, relative to a sere or succession.

a succession (q.v.) or stage in a succession, e.g. lithosere: a sere on rock (or stone); psammosere: on sand; xerosere: in aridity; subsere: arising from a disturbed habitat; prisere: from a completely changed habitat.
of hairs when silk-like, or of a surface when silky haired. From L. sericatus, clothed in silk.

of plants, a biochemical approach to classification through the assessment of the reactive property of the plant's protein as an antigen when in the form of an extract or serum, it is introduced to protein from another source.
flowering late in the season; late maturing. From L. serus, late.
creeping.
as in serpyllifolium, of wild thyme Thymus (Labiatae).
as in serrate, serriform, notched, like the cutting-edge of a saw.
of a margin when sharply indented to appear like the forward-pointing teeth of a saw.
the diminutive condition of serrate.
of a structure when borne without a supporting part, e.g. the petiole of a leaf, the filament of an anther, the pedicel of a flower etc.
as in sesquiterpene, one and a half (hence with one and a half times the carbon and hydrogen atoms of true terpenes, C₁₀H₈ i.e. with empiric formula C₁₅H₂₄).
as in setaceous, setose, setigerous, a bristle.
of a surface when covered by bristle-like hair.
as in sexfid, six (from sex), or as in sexual, sex (from sexus).
of inheritance when the factor(s) for a character(s) is(are) linked in the chromosome (sex chromosome) carrying sex-determining genes.
see under reproduction.
a laminated sediment with clay texture.

of geology, a region of very ancient rocks compacted at an early stage to a solid mass resistant to later disturbances. A physical structure typical of lands with low relief, as the continent of Australia.
a stem considered with the parts arising from it, e.g. foliage and inflorescence.
a woody plant usually not above twenty feet in height of which apical dominance (q.v.) is replaced at an early growth-stage by lateral branching so that no single stem is dominant.
the rocks forming the upper part of the earth and underlying the continents, compounded from silicon and aluminium, elements contained by granite, an acidic rock.
so, in this manner.
as in desiccate, exsiccate, to dry (hence, in common usage, to dry, and a substance or material freed from moisture respectively).
of the stars; glittering.
as in siderophloia, iron (hence 'iron-barked').

a unit of phloem concerned in the translocation of synthesised substances, either a sieve-cell when simple or a sieve-tube member when one of a series forming a sieve-tube, an elongate cell enucleate when functional with primary wall modified by a perforated region traversed by cytoplasmic strands ensheathed by callose (q.v.).
Especially of the end-walls of angiosperms, perforated regions, sieve areas, occur in definite parts of the sieve-tube member, the part known as a sieve plate. A frequent association is a proteinaceous viscous substance, slime, contained by the vacuole of the member and originating from slime bodies of various form and number. See also Companion Cell.
with the shape of the letter S.
as in signatus, signorum, to mark; to adorn.
of, or with the nature of, silica or sand. From L. silex, flint.
a siliqua (q.v.) when short and flat. e.g. of Capsella and Coronopus.

a capsular fruit derived from a bicarpellate ovary with a dissepiment (false septum), dehiscent from the base upwards and with the two valves remaining attached to the tip of the septum. Chiefly of Cruciferae. From L. siliqua, a pod.
of soil, the fraction in which the size of particles varies from 0.02 mm to 0.002 mm (the upper limit for clay).
as in silvaticus, silvestris, a woodland or forest.
the art of forest management from the aspects of protection, regeneration, maintenance and utilisation of the crop.
the rocks underlying the sial (q.v.) and the surface of the ocean floor, the word compounded from silicon and magnesium, elements contained by basalt, a basic rock.
resembling.
simple; of a single series or kind.
of Chinese origin.
spiralling to the left, from L. sinistrors(us), to the left.
of a margin when alternatively deeply concave and convex.
in general, a cavity or recess.
as in siphonogamous, a tube (hence fertilising through a pollen-tube.
a stele when in the form of a hollow cylinder enclosing a central core of parenchyma. Especially of ferns. See also dictyostele.
of soil, relative to the type in which the parent rock is close to the surface and imperfectly weathered or consolidated to stone. A feature of tableland and range.
see scia-
of a forest, the accumulated litter from leaf and branch shed.
an inclusion, e.g. of a sieve-tube member, proteinaceous in nature, which disperses as a slime.
see under fungus.
of plant disease, one caused by a member of the order Ustilaginales of the Basidiomycetes (see under fungus).
bearing or producing a number of creeping and rooting stems below the surface of the soil, e.g. Couch grass Cynodon spp. From L. soboles, an offshoot.

the weathered superficial layer of the earth's crust together with the flora and fauna (edaphon) present within, and the products of their decay.

Azonal: without a well-developed profile either through immaturity or by a prevention of the weathering process from the parent material.
Brown (including Grey): a soil group possessing free lime throughout the profile, little contrast in texture, and low content of organic matter although with moderate fertility. Occurs widely throughout the semi-arid region of the continent, in virgin state supports communities ranging from grassland to shrub steppe.
Heavy: when the texture is clay, named from the aspect of working.
Immature: when developing from recently-laid deposits or denuded horizons and not appearing with definite profile.
Intazonal: with a profile reflecting a very moderate or slight influence of climate and vegetation on its development.
Light: when the texture is sand, named from the aspect of working.
Zonal: with a profile reflecting a dominant influence of climate and vegetation on its development. See also texture.
as in aerosol, a colloidal solution (hence one in a gaseous phase).
of the sun; solar.
of photosynthesis, an inhibition when the intensity of light extends beyond its saturation.
as in solenogyne, a tube.
a siphonostele (q.v.).

of an inflorescence when a flower arises singly from within the axil of a leaf of a vegetative shoot (the inflorescence then solitary- and axillary-flowered) or a single flower terminates a vegetative shoot without other flowers directly below it (the inflorescence then solitary-flowered and terminal).

of soil, the leaching of colloids (clays) to some depth by their replacement with sodium ions (see cation exchange), the general effect being that the solonised soil is either high in content of sodium salts (then a solonchak) or is highly alkaline in reaction (then a solonetz). Both soil groups are of extensive occurrence in the low rainfall regions (i.e. less than 17 inches) of southern Australia: in the virgin state, the community typically supported is a mallee scrub (q.v.) in South Australia, western Victoria and New South Wales, and a salmon gum (Eucalyptus salmonophloia) woodland in Western Australia. From Russian solonet, to become salty.
in one sense, of mid-summer or summer heat. Also of a summer-growing plant or an ephemeral.
of a solute, the maximum mass dissolvable in a standard mass of solvent at a given temperature.
of a solution, the substance (solid, liquid, gas) dissolved by the dispersing medium, the solvent, e.g. water, known as the universal solvent.
the dispersal of a solute in a solvent to form a homogenous mixture, true when not an emulsion or colloidal solution.
a body. In soma, somatic, somatogenic, in relation to a plant, the vegetative body as distinct from the reproductive. In chromosome, ribosome, sphaerosome, a body in the sense of a particle.

the division of a vegetative cell to two parts with equal sharing of the content of chromosomes, mitochondria and other organelles of the original (parent) cell. A second division of nuclei (karyokinesis or mitosis) and cytoplasm (cytokinesis) restores to each the original content of the parent, and eventual reorganisation of nuclear membranes and cell walls lead to the establishment of the parts as individual identities.
of nutrition when stimulating vegetative growth.
as in sonic, sound.
the subjection of a substance to an ultra-high frequency of sound produced by a 'sonifer'. A method of precipitating substances from suspension by vibrations.
as in sonchus, hollow. From Gk. somphos.
relative to a sorus or to sori.
to suck up. In absorb, adsorb, sorbefacient, sorption, the intake or uptake of a substance.
a heap.
of spore-bearing plants, a cluster of sporangia.
resembling a spadix.
with the colour of the date (the fruit of Phoenix).
bearing a spadix, or spadices.

(plural spadices) a spike (q.v.) with a fleshy-textured (succulent) axis, the flowers often partly embedded. From L. spadix, a palm-branch, the inflorescence of a palm (e.g. Phoenix) being a panicle of spadices each subtended by a sometimes woody spathe.
of distribution when of scattered occurrence, i.e. occurring in a number of unconnected localities.
as in spartothamnus, cordage.
a bract or leaf, sometimes petaloid, enclosing at least in the bud stage a spadix. From L. spatha, a two-edged broad sword.
bearing, or resembling, a spathe.
a spoon.
of a lamina when the apex is broad and rounded, and tapered to the base, somewhat in the form of a spoon or spatula.
the evolution of species by the segmentation of a previously continuous population into two or more populations which are morphologically discontinuous and reproductively isolated from one another.

of classification, a category below the level of a genus; a category basic to a classificatory scheme. As a taxonomic group, one uniting individuals with genotypic and phenotypic similarities, which breed freely among themselves (or have the potential for such) and are reproductively isolated from other groups. From L. species, an appearance; a model.
relative to a species, or to a definite object or character.
the condition of being specific. The limitation of a factor to a species or to a definite object or character.
beautiful.
as in specularia, a mirror.
as in spelaecolous, a cave (hence cave-dwelling.
as in angiosperm, angiospermous, leptospermum, spermatophyte, a seed.

the male gamete. Of conifers and angiosperms, developed as a nucleus within a pollen-tube but in other fertilising groups (algae, bryophytes, pteridophytes, cycads) a flagellate cell actively motile (a spermatozoid) formed within usually definite structures, antheridia.
withered; decayed. From Gk. sphakelos, gangrene.
globular; ellipsoid; spherical.
a globular inclusion of cytoplasm with unknown function.
as in spheroid, spherical, sphaerocarpous, atmosphere, a globe or ball.
as in sphenoid, a wedge.

a pteridophyte (q.v.) differentiated to a definite jointed and ribbed stem, whorled and minute leaves (microphylls) ensheathing the node of the stem, and adventitious roots developed from a rhizome. Eusporangiate sporangia are borne on special structures (sporangiophores) collected into a terminal spike-like strobilus. The prothallus is free-living (exosporic); the male gametes are multiflagellate.
A member of a class Equisetae or Sphenopsida of some authors, or a division Calamophyta of others, with history dating to the Devonian period, reaching optimum development during the Carboniferous periods when both arborescent and herbaceous habits were adopted. The surviving genus, Equisetum, (order Equisetales) of about 23 herbaceous species with sympodial branching, is chiefly of the northern hemisphere, usually aquatic or associated with wet or moist habitats, absent from Australia.
as in sphenotome, to cleave.
pollination by hawkmoths.
as in spicate, spiciferous, spicigerous, spicose, a spike.
as in spiculate, spiculigerous, a small spike (hence bearing needle-like bodies, spicules).
an unbranched indeterminate inforescence (a simple raceme) with sessile flowers.
of a grass, the unit of an inflorescence subtended by a pair a bracts (glumes) and bearing up to 5 florets, each floret axillary within a palea.

of plants, a sharp sclerified structure formed from a leaf, either modified from part of it as in the Yuccas and Agaves (apex and margin) and certain acacias (e.g. Acacia farnesiana where formed by a stipule), or replacing the leaf as in the gorse Ulex europaeus. cf. thorn.
of a lamina or branch when terminating in a spine-like point.

of a grassland community, or the dominant grass of the community, when developed on sand-dunes. When the dune is littoral, Spinifex hirsutus often is the dominant where it is a pioneer sand-binder; when of the sandy desert of the eremaean and occurring in dense, tussock-like masses, Triodia basedowii is the usual dominant.
bearing spines or thorns.
bearing small spines or thorns.
as in spiriferous, spiroid, spirochaete, a coil or spiral.
as in spirillar, spirillum, a small coil.
epithet, shining; glistening.
as in spongiose, a sponge (hence of open or porous texture; spongy).
as in sporangial, sporophyte, microspore, a spore.
of distribution when not continuous, i.e. scattered.
a stalk-like structure supporting a sporangium, e.g. an aerial hyphae of a fungus; the structure forming the cone of a sphenopsid.

a cell or structure within which spores are produced. When the spores are dimorphic (i.e. the plant heterosporous), a microsporangium when producing microspores (e.g. the sporangium contained by each of the four anther-lobes of an angiosperm), and megasporangium when producing mega-spores (e.g. the sporogenous cells within an ovule).

a cell or (rarely) a group of cells concerned in reproduction, usually asexual and formed from meiotic division of spore mother-cells (hence haploid in genetic condition), giving eventual rise to the gametophyte through, e.g. germination to a prothallus. When dimorphic (e.g. of the heterosporous groups of gymnosperms and angiosperms), either a microspore (e.g. a pollen-grain) or a megaspore (the mother-cell of the female prothallus or (angiosperms) embryo-sac). See also under fungus. See also meiospere, mitospore, and under the various taxonomic groups.
of a heterosporous fern (e.g. Marsilea) see under fern; of a fungus, a fruiting-body.
spore-producing.
see under bryophyte.
in general, a structure bearing spores.

in general, a leaf or leaf-order part bearing a sporangium (or sporangia), e.g. as a unit of the cone or strobilus of the lycopods, gymnosperms, the stamen and carpel of angiosperms. When a male structure, a microsporophyll, when female megasporophyll.
of a plant with an alternation of generations (q.v.), the asexual spore-producing, genetically diploid generation, represented in vascular plants by the conspicuous vegetative body.
the product of a somatic mutation, the phenotypic character so modified that the individual may be continued as a clone but not as a genetically distinct segregate.
the formation and release of spores.
of a structure when extending transversely or outwardly.
frothing; foaming.

of a corolla or perianth, a slender, long, hollow prolongation of the lower part (or parts). Well-marked in the commonly cultivated 'Snap-dragons' of Antirrhinum as well as several orchids. See also gibbous.
false in the sense of resembling but without the anatomic or morphologic structure, e.g. a dissepiment of an ovary or fruit when appearing like a true septum.
as in squamate, squamose, squamous, squamiform, a scale (hence covered by scales or scale-like bracts (squamae))..
roughened by prominent projections.
as in stachystemon, brachystachya, an ear of corn (hence in the sense of a spike).
the unit an androecium typically comprising a pollen-bearing anther and a supporting filament. The microsporophyll of angiosperms, basically of leaf rank.
relative to a stamen.
of a flower when its functionally fertile parts are all stamens. cf. pistillate.
bearing stamens.

(plural staminodes) a sterile stamen-like floral part (of some flowers), sometimes representing a transition to a petal or a rudimentary stamen, in some cases, a nectary. Also staminodium (plural staminodia).
an area occupied by a stable community or a group of plants forming a concrete community, usually in the sense of a single species.
of a papilionaceous flower, the uppermost petal, distinct and usually larger than the other petals. A vexillum.
as in staphylococcus, staphylocarpus, a bunch (of grapes); a cluster.

a polysaccharide, usually made up of two components amylose and amylopectin, the major reserve carbohydrate of plants where it is stored at various sites, e.g. within stems, tubers, roots. Synthesised in chloroplasts but with little known origin and manner of synthesis, appears in a granule (leucoplast) of various size and form as a series of concentric layers. It is readily broken down by the enzyme phosphorylase to glucose phosphate from which it is derived and through the amylase group of enzymes may be converted to maltose, further hydrolysis by maltase leading to glucose (the complete hydrolysis may be duplicated by boiling with dilute acid). Reactant with iodine to give a deep blue colour. Forms a sol with hot water which gels on cooling.
as in stasimorphic, stasis, bacteriostatic, thermostat, a standing (still) hence used in the sense of an arrest or an equilibrium.
as in stauranthus, staurochilus, a cross.
as in steatocarpa, fat; tallow.
as in steganthum, calystegia, a covering.
as in protostele, siphonostele, a pillar; a column.
the primary arrangement of a vascular system. The central vascular cylinder of a root-shoot system developed from a plerome.
as in stellaris, stellate, a star.
in general, radiating from a common centre to appear star-like. Of epidermal hair when several hairs arise from a common centre and lie flat.
the basic axial organ of a plant which, with its appendages, forms the shoot.
as in cryptostemma, a crown.
as in callistemon, stemodia, a thread. Extended to mean a stamen or stamened. e.g. in stemodia, stemo(n)di(s) twice, the four stamens in two pairs.
as in stenomerous, stenophyllous, narrow.
of distribution when within a restricted geographic range.
as in stephanocarpa, a crown.

a community of saline soils, a shrub steppe when the dominants are halophilous semi-erect and semi-succulent shrubs, e.g. of the arid and semi-arid regions of the continent where saltbush (of Atriplex, Rhagodia, Bassia etc.) and bluebush (Kochia) are dominants.
as in sterculia, of manure or dung (hence a reference to a somewhat fetid odour).
as in stereophylla, stiff; rigid; solid.
of a compound when occurring in two or more chemically and physically different forms (isomers) due to the different arrangements in space possible of the atoms of its molecule.

not fertile, e.g. for reproduction. Aseptic. Of soil when below optimum in nutrients available for active plant growth. Male sterile: of a plant with a genetic system carrying factors for male sterility, the plant thus 'self-emasculating'.
(plural sterigmata) of fungi, a supporting structure for a sporangium, conidium, or basidiospore. From Gk. sterigma, support.
resembling or chemically related to a sterol (e.g. a saponin), or the substance featuring this property.

an unsaturated alcohol of complex ring structure, universally distributed in plants but of unknown significance. Of high commercial interest for its value as a starting material in the preparation of synthetic hormones (e.g. sitosterol from the seeds of several monocots, stigmasterol from the seeds of the soya bean) and vitamins (e.g. ergosterol from yeast). Sterols from certain fungi have been considered as an intermediate in the synthesis of cortisone, a drug of clinical use in the treatment of arthritic complaints, certain skin diseases, and forms of cancer.
as in distichous, a row; a line.
as in sticta, spotted.
of a carpel, the part which carries the pollen-receptive stigmatic tissue, frequently continuous with the ovary by a style.
a stigma of primitive form reduced to a ridge along the margins of the carpel, e.g. of Drimys (Winteraceae). Also stigmatic crest.
a land with unchanging base-level, e.g. the Wianamatta Stillstand encircling the city of Sydney where no warping has occurred since its formation in the late Triassic.
bearing stinging hairs. From L. stimulus, a sting; a stimulus.
in general, a supporting structure or stalk. Of a carpel, a basal supporting projection. cf. gynophore. From L. stipes, a stalk.
a stipule, or segment of a stipule, at the base of a leaflet.
bearing stipels.
borne on a stipe or stalk. Also stipose.
a lateral part of a leaf borne either near or at the base of the leaf, one on each side, or on the stem free from the lamina but originating from the leaf-base.
with stipules.

of a grafting, the rooted plant receiving the introduced scion.

Of heredity, the descendants in line from an original ancestor, ie. lineage.
French Lavender (Lavandula latifolia).

a shoot curving towards the ground and developing adventitious roots, each section of stem with its root on division (or layering) with the potential for independence from the parent. Often a synonym of runner.
developing or bearing stolons.
a mouth; an opening or pore.

(plural stomates) one of the numerous perforations of a leaf epidermis through which ensues the gaseous exchange during photosynthetic and respiratory processes and the transpiration of water vapour to the atmosphere. A pore formed by two crescent-shaped guard-cells which, through changes in their turgidity, control the opening and closing of the pore. Also stoma (plural stomata).
(plural stomia) of a sporangium, a region or opening formed by thin walled cells, or by their splitting apart, with consequent release or dehiscence of spores.
a sclereid (q.v.).
a succulent fruit with a hardened or woody endocarp (the stone). A drupe. See also putamen.
with the texture of straw. From L. stramen, straw.

of a plant community, the arrangement of strata (or layers) made up by the aggregation of plants of similar habit, ranging from a tall stratum, e.g. of forest trees, to a low stratum, e.g. of mosses on the forest floor. Of rock, an arrangement in dennite layers (strata) indicating a difierence in formation.

of seed dormant from the need of after-ripening (q.v.), treatment by chilling under moist conditions for a period of time varying from a few days to several months, according to species, at a temperature from -1° to 4°C. e.g. the seed of Snow Gum Eucalyptus pauciflora, as a general practice, is held for four days at a temperature of 4º before sowing.
as in stratified, stratose, substratum, a layer; a covering.
(plural strata) of ecology, a layer or level in a community formed by plants of similar habit, e.g. a tree, shrub, or herbaceous stratum. Of geology, a layer of rock.
as in streptococcus, twisted (hence a general appearance when the cocci form a chain).

of a surface when marked by longitudinal lines or channels.

Of venation when the veins are several to numerous, fine, and parallel with the margin.
of habit when erect and straight.
the diminutive of strigose. From L. strigilla, a small ridge.
of a surface when appressed by straight and stiff hairs or bristles. From L. striga, a ridge.

of geology, the general horizontal direction of a stratum. As an adjective, e.g. strike fault, relative to features roughly parallel with the strike. The downward slope of a stratum, taken from the horizontal (or strike) is dip.

of eucalypts, a member of a botanic group (Pachyphloia) typified by a bark persistent, with texture thick, rather spongy, stringy from long fibres, capable of being pulled awey from the trunk in long wide strips, grey or reddish-brown in colour. A eucalypt of the eastern coast and tablelands, or of Tasmania and (Eucalyptus baxteri) of South Australia, commonly a commercial timber tree with wood very durable and brown in colour. Frequently planted as a shade and shelter tree, it may also be a valuable source of pollen or nectar for the bee-keeper. Included also are some mallees, or small trees, e.g. E. camfieldii, E. alpina both of restricted occurrence.
The common name designating the stringybark may be based on the colour of the wood, e.g. Red Stringybark Eucalyptus macrorrhyncha (a commercial source of rutin) with a pink tinge to a light-brown colour, Brown E. capitellata, White E. globoidea not white but often paler than normal. Other namemay refer to the colour of the inner bark, e.g. Yellow E. muelleriana, or to the foliage, e.g. Silver-leaf E. laevopinea, Blue-leaved E. agglomerata, Narrow-leaved E. oblonga, Broad-leaved E. caliginosa.
Messmate Stringybark E. obliqua and Mountain Ash E. regnans chiefly of Victoria and Tasmania, and Brown Barrel E. fastigata of the tablelands of New South Wales and adjoining Victoria are atypical in the bark character, the fibre being much shorter, the bark of E. regnans persistent only at the base of the trunk. The three are tall, shaft-like timber trees, usually are associated with the Ash group (q.v.). Other stringybarks of note are E. youmanii (also a source of rutin) of the northern tablelands of New South Wales and E. blaxlandii of the Blue Mountains of this State.
as in striolate, a small channel (hence finely striate).
resembling a strobilus. From Gk. strobilos, a fir-cone.
(plural strobili) a reproductive structure when composed of an axis bearing sporophylls, as the cone-like structure of conifers and lycopods.
(plural stromata) of a fungus, a spore-producing mass of hyphae, sometimes hardened and sclerotium-like.
a spiral or helix. strombulos, the diminutive.
as in strongylocarpa, rounded.
as in strophanthus, a twisting or turning.
of a seed, an aril (q.v.) when restricted to a crest. Strophiolate: bearing a strophiole. From L. strophiolum, a small garland.
as in strophotaxis, twisted.

of ecology, the spatial arrangement of plants within a community without reference to the individual members. Structural forms within the continent include bog, feldmark, grassland, heath, saltbush, scrub, mallee, woodland, sclerophyll forest, rainforest. Categories for structural groupings include formation and sub-formation.

 of soil, the arrangement of primary particles and their adherence in clusters (as aggregates) which collectively characterise its physical properties. cf. texture.
as in strumose, strumiform, a small tumour (hence with, or in the form of, a cushion-like swelling).
with a tuft of matted filaments. From L. stupa, tow.
relative to a style. From Gk. stylos, a column.
of a carpel, a sterile, usually filamentous part connecting a stigma with the ovary and through which an 'accepted' pollen-grain develops its tube.
as in stypandra, tow; waste flax or hemp, short and broken in texture.
as in styphelia, hard-textured.
sweet-smelling. Also suaveolens.
as in subsoil, substrate, underlying; as in sub-sessile, sub-marginal, almost: as in sub-microscopic, less than: as in sub-species, below.
as in subereous, suberiferous, suberin, cork.

a cork-like substance formed by derivatives of fatty acids, impermeable to steam and water and with low thermal conductivity. Chemically related to cutin, in the plant it is incorporated in the walls of the cork cells of phellum.
the deposition or incorporation of suberin in cell walls.
with the texture of cork.
high, lofty.

a substance which passes, when heated or vaporised, directly from the solid to the gaseous state without formation of a liquid, i.e. its melting point is higher than the point of temperature when its vapour pressure equals the atmospheric pressure.
of size when less than that discernible or resolved by the highest powers of the light microscope.
in general, the soil below from six to eight inches from the surface (i.e. below the topsoil or plough depth).
a category below the level of a species. A taxonomic group within a species united, e.g. by geographic or ecologic distinction. Often used as a synonym of variety.
of a fermentative organism (fungus, bacterium), or enzyme, the substance activated or catalysed.
(plural substrata) a layer (e.g. of soil, rock), especially in the sense that it provides a place for growth.
to stand below or close under, as a bract subtending a flower.
fine, delicate; finely woven; subtile.
of a lamina when very narrow (its breadth almost equalling its depth) and tapered to a very fine point, to appear like an awl.
of ecology, the progressive change in structure of a vegetation from initial colonisation to ultimate climax.
of amber.

as an adjective, of soft and fleshy texture. As a noun, a plant adapted to conditions of aridity or salinity by the production of abundant water-storing tissue and a means for reducing transpiration, e.g. development of a heavily cutinised epidermis, by sunken stomates, by the shaping of succulent parts to structures with the least surface to greatest volume, i.e. structures cylindrical, prismatic, spherical.
With a reduction of the surface for transpiration, there is consequent reduction of photosynthetic and respiratory activity, and growth-rate. Succulents are perennials often of long life, for some (e.g. Cactaceae, some Euphorbia) a succulent stem (cladode) has taken over the function of the leaf, in others (e.g. Mesembryanthemum, samphires and other chenopodiaceous halophytes), the leaves are succulent, often cylindrical or prismatic and in rosettes from short internodes of the stem.
juice; sap.
a shoot developed from a root or (as from a lignotuber) from a stem close to or below soil level. Suckering: the process of forming suckers.
of an herbaceous perennial with that part of the stem immediately above soil level more or less woody and perennial.

one of the carbohydrates (q.v.) when of crystalline form, with high solubility and sweetness in taste. In general, either a monosaccharide (e.g. glucose) or disaccharide (e.g. sucrose). When a monosaccharide, is either an aldose when containing a -CHO aldehyde group (e.g. glucose) or a ketose when containing a -CO ketone group (e.g. fructose).
of swine.
of a surface when grooved or furrowed. From L. sulcus, a furrow.
resembling, or with the colour (pale yellow) of, sulphur.
as in superficial, supernatant, above, on top of.
outstanding.
of a liquid when cooled to a temperature below its freezing point without the formation of the solid state, crystallisation thus being delayed.
in general, at a higher level (in space), as an ovary of a hypogenous flower which has the other floral parts inferior to it.
in general, floating on the surface. Of a two or more phased fluid system, the uppermost phase.

calcium hydrogen phosphate Ca(H₂PO₄)₂ together with calcium and other metallic sulphates present as impurities. The water-soluble product, used as a source of available phosphorus for plant growth, derived by controlled treatment of the insoluble calcium phosphate Ca₃(PO₄)₂ with concentrated sulphuric acid, its quality quoted on the basis of phosphorus pentoxide P₂O₅ content.

of a solution when remaining as such while cooled to below the temperature at which saturation by the solute is obtained, crystallisation occurring when the solution is in contact with a solid form of the solute.
a hypothetical ancestral form or stock from which closely related species were derived.
leaning backwards. From L. supinus.
as in supra-axillary, above, upper (hence arising immediately above an axil).
a shoot
an agent, e.g. a soap, wetting agent, detergent, with the ability even in low concentration to reduce the surface tension of water. Also surface active agent.

of a liquid, a property, measurable as a force, which tends to confine the volume in the least space available. Since there is attraction of molecules to each other, the attraction of the molecular layer at the surface will be equal in horizontal direction but unequal in vertical direction, the positive attraction being towards the centre of the liquid. The unbalanced attraction effects a force, maximum at the surface which appears to act as an elastic membrane. The force usually is expressed in dynes (one dyne is approximately equal to the gravitational force of one milligram), e.g. surface tension force of pure water is 13 dynes which may be lowered by the addition of a surfactant (q.v.).
for a cell or organism, an index of the proportion of surface area available for diffusion in relation to its volume, a sphere having the least surface area for unit volume.

of seed-plants, a single cell, a row of cells or (in gymnosperms) a multiseriate layer of cells developed from a zygote within an embryo sac or archegonium, which positions the zygote or its pro-embryo to the region of endosperm.
relative to a suture.
a line marking the junction of two parts when meeting, or a furrow made when a single part is infolded.
see silv(a).

term: sym- (before b, m and p), syn- Gk.
meaning: as in symbiosis, sympetalous, synandra, synergid, synsepalous, together, united.
an organism living symbiotically.

in a narrow sense, an association of organisms with an effect of mutual benefit. In a general sense, an association which may be either not constant, or with the symbionts not in close contact (i.e. disjunctive symbiosis) or both close and constant (conjunctive symbiosis). When disjunctive, the benefit may be nutritive, either at the expense of one (e.g. carnivorous plants and their prey) or reciprocal (e.g. dispersal of seed through ingestion by an animal of its fruit). When disjunctive and not nutritive, one plant may effect benefit to another (e.g. by casting trade of providing some other factor of habitat required by the other).
Parasitism is a conjunctive symbiosis with a nutritive benefit for one but at the expense of the other. Mutualism is conjunctive and of reciprocal benefit, e.g. of lichens, nitrogen-fixing bacteria, mycorrhiza), Commensalism is conjunctive but not nutritive, it benefits one (the commensal, e.g. a liana or epiphyte) but not the other. See also amensalism.
living in symbiosis.
the regularity of form or similarity of structure on each side of an axis, the condition of being symmetrical.
of distribution when duplicated in the same or overlapping regions. cf. allopatric.
of a corolla with petals connate by their margins.
as in symphionema, united.
as in symplocos, a connection.
relative to, or resembling, a sympodium.
a branching system where apical dominance (q.v.) is replaced by lateral development. cf. monopodium.
of meiosis (q.v.), the pairing of homologous chromosomes (bivalents) at zygonema.
as in synaptantha, joined.
a fruit when multiple and formed from several more or less coalescent carpels.
of a multicarpellate gynaecium when the carpel walls are fused to form a single ovary.
occurring at the same time; contemporary. cf. allochronic.
see under fold.
of disease, the complexity of factors (symptoms) apparent.
ecology from the aspect of the community.
relative to an increase in the development or rate of a reaction by an association of two factors, one (the synergid) by itself unreactive.
of reproduction when involving a fusion of gametes, i.e. fertilisation.
of an androecium when the anthers are united to form a column around the style, often the filaments free, e.g. of Compositae.
of a calyx when the sepals are connate by their margins.
the cohesion of stamens by their filaments or anthers alone or by both.
relative to the building-up (synthesis) of a complex from its essential parts. cf. analytic.

research attempting, by the use of criteria drawn from current biologic science and techniques, e.g. classification, taxonomy and nomenclature, a logical order of knowledge concerning the diversity and relationships of organisms.

of an insecticide, e.g. metasystox and certain other organophosphate compounds, when its action concerns a translocation by the plant where applied (at a concentration not toxic to the plant) to regions of insect feeding at a concentration lethal to the insect.
as in syringa, a tube; a pipe.
as in syzygium, coupled (hence, in the genus, a reference to the opposite nature of the leaves).
in general, a plateau (q.v.) but sometimes restricted to one when its slope is abrupt and cliff-like and rises from the surrounding lowland in strong relief.
as in tachysporous, quick.
rapidly dehiscing or dispersing seed or spore.
relative to a movement (a taxis) in a direction positive or negative to the source of a stimulus, or to the stimulus inducing such motion. From Gk. taktos, arranged.
sensitive to touch, e.g. the pulvinus of the Sensitive Plants of Mimosa. From L. tactilis, that may be touched.
a strap or ribbon, taeniola, the diminutive.
as in taetrolens, offensive (hence evil-smelling).
the accumulated debris from the gravitational fall of fragmented rocks from cliffs and rocky slopes.

an aromatic acid of diverse and complex nature occurring naturally throughout the plant kingdom in cells or sacs (usually within vacuoles) of tissues or sites of various nature but with unknown significance, possibly as a side product of a metabolic process. In the plant it has been shown to possess fungistatic properties and, chemically, has the property of precipitating from solution proteins and alkaloids and (usually) yields green, blue, or black precipitates with ferric salts. In taste it is bitter and astringent.
When water-soluble, with acidic reaction, and readily hydrolysed by boiling dilute acid or the enzyme tannase to gallic acid and glucose, generally referred to as a tannin. Where more complex and not readily hydrolysed, is often a catechol or derivative. Both types may be oxidised to coloured phlobaphenes which appear as red or dark-brown pigments of woody tissues and bark (and probably are the dark spots prominent in the leaves of dried essential oil-bearing leaves, e.g. of myrtaceous and rutaceous plants.
A property of the tanning substance in converting crude hide to stable leather creates a commercial demand. A number of Australian plants are, or have been, commercial sources, e.g. the Wattle Barks chiefly of Acacia mearnsii, A. pycnantha, A. irrorata, Mallet Bark (chiefly Brown Mallet Eucalyptus astringens) and to a more limited extent Mangrove Bark from several native mangroves. Such barks have sufficiently high tannin content to be used directly. Other barks with tannin high in quality but low in content are processed, the extract being the marketable product. Wandoo bark from Eucalyptus wandoo yields a solid extract, myrtan, of high commercial interest. See also under gall.
a section cut lengthwise from a cylindrical structure so that it occurs at right-angles to a radius of the transverse section.
relative to a tapetum.
a nutritive layer investing sporogenous tissue within a sporangium. From L. tapetum, drapery; tapestry.
as in taphrophyte, a ditch.
the primary persistent root typical of dicots and gymnosperms from which lateral roots are developed in acropetal succession.
as in tautonym, the same (hence a name duplicated for both genus and species).
as in taxon, taxonomy, monotaxis, phyllotaxy, an arrangement in an order.
as in taxifolia, of the Yew Taxus (from Gk. taxon, a bow).
movement (in toto) as a response to a stimulus, e.g. by a motile alga when stimulated by light (then a phototaxis).
(plural taxa) a taxonomic unit. A group of plants sharing a relationship (i.e. a taxonomic group) which may be assigned to one of the categories of a classification.
relative to a feature of classification or of taxonomy.
the study of the principles involved in a system of classification and the formulation of these principles to clear and definite rules and procedures.
as in tecticornia, tectifera, tectorum, a covering; a roof.
relative to the structure of rock resultant from movements of the earth's crust, i.e. relative to the tectonosphere. From Gk. tekton, a builder.
at a distance; far off (hence telopea seen at a distance).

water held by the earth; underground water, e.g. much of the mesophytic flora of monsoonal Australia (including the Kimberley region) is dependent on water stored by the earth during a six months drought period, the water brought by rains of the wet season. From L. tellus, the earth; soil.
complete; pertect.
an end.

of climatology, relative to the region north (for the Northern Hemisphere) and south of approximately latitude 30° to the upper limit of the polar regions at approximately 66° (1° is equivalent roughly to 69 miles). In Australia the region marked by rainfall with a winter incidence but rarely entirely absent over the seasons, and relatively low to moderate relative humidity and temperature.

In Australian phytogeography, a floristic zone traversing the southern coast and inland of the continent and including Tasmania, i.e. from the south-west province of Western Australia eastwards through the region marked by rainfall in excess of 10 inches and northwards to latitude 26°, thus overlapping the tropical zone, and southwards to include Tasmania. Within the zone, 'temperate' climatic conditions vary from cool temperate to sub-tropical, and rainfall from uniform throughout the year to a summer or winter incidence.
tough; tenacious.
a twisting thread-like segment of a leaf or stem functioning for the securing of a hold on a support.
thin; fine; delicate.

the wood (reaction wood) of dicots when modified by a physical state of growth, e.g. by the lateral position of a branch when the wood on the upper side is reduced in number and size of vessels and its fibres thickened by cellulose. cf. compression wood (of conifers).
a unit of a perianth, either sepaloid or petaloid.
as in tephrosia, tephrous, ashy; ash-coloured.
as in rupester, rupestre (from rupes, a cliff), campestris (from campus, a plain), suffixes indicating of a habitat.
the study of abnormal development; of plants tumours, galls and other malformations. From Gk. teras, a monster.
boring into; perforating.
as in terete, tereticornis, rounded (in cross-section, usually also in the sense of the structure being tapered).
at the tip of, apical. In epithets, e.g. terminalis, usually indicating the placement of structures (e.g. leaves) at one end (e.g. of a leaf-shoot).
as in ternate, three together. ter: three times.
of leaves when arising in three's from the same node, or of leaflets when forming a trifoliolate leaf.

a hydrocarbon, unsaturated and usually monocyclic, with molecular formula a multiple of isoprene C₅H₈ (e.g. limonene C₁₀H₁₆). Usually a colourless, aromatic liquid, immiscible in water but volatile in steam, chemically reactive and often readily undergoing polymerisation and isomerisation (e.g. limonene, pinene, phellandrene, isomeric monoterpenes common constituents of essential oils).
Of general occurrence within plants, e.g. as constituents of essential oils usually as a monoterpene (C₁₀H₁₆) which may be reduced to an alcohol, aldehyde or ketone, a sesquiterpene (C₁₆H₂₄) or a diterpene (C₂₀H₃₂). Diterpenes and triterpenes (C₃₀H₄₈) are constituents of resins and latex, tetraterpenes (C₄₀H₆₄) of carotenes, and polyterpenes (C₅H₈)n of rubber.
as in terraneous, terricolous, terrestrial, earth, the planet Earth.
a region of land considered from the aspect of relief, physical features, soil, drainage, and vegetation.
as in tertiary, the third. Tertio: for the third time.
checkered, marked in a pattern of squares.
a seed-coat representing the usually hardened integuments of the ovule. From L. testa, a shell.
with a shape resembling a testicle, as the tuber of many orchids, the name orchis taken from the Greek meaning a testicle or testis.
as in tetrandrous, tetragonal, four.
a group of four; the four spores formed by meiotic divisions of a spore mother-cell.
of stamens when occurring in a flower four long and in pairs opposite to each other and alternating with two solitary shorter ones.
with four angles.
of four parts.
of a flower with four stamens.
of a genetic system with four times the number of chromosomes basic to the species. A polyploid with this nature.
with four wing-like structures.
with four loculi or theca (e.g. of anthers).
textile; woven.

of soil, the proportions, by weight, of the component particles of different size. The particle size and its conventional name correspond to some arbitrary system as that in use in Australia:

gravel ... greater than 2 mm. diameter.
 coarse sand ... 2 mm. to 0.2 mm. diameter.
fine sand ... 0.2 mm. to 0.02 mm. diameter.
silt ... 0.02 mm. to 0.002 mm. diameter.
clay ... less than 0.002 mm. diameter.

In a general sense, soil texture may be expressed on the basis of the component which characterises its consistency, e.g. a coarse-textured soil is taken as one in which sand particles are well-represented, and is referred also as a light soil from its relative ease of working. A fine-textured soil contains much clay and, although lighter in weight per unit volume than sand, is called heavy from its toughness and plasticity in working. Intermediate to these is loam in which both coarse and fine particles are equally represented. Where gravel or silt (silt in the sense of an alluvium of very fine sand) are appreciable, the qualifying 'gravelly' and 'silty' are used.
Intermediate textures from sand to loam in increasing order of fineness and cohesion conventionally are loamy sand, sandy loam, loam, and from loam to clay, sandy clay loam, clay loam, sandy clay.
as in thalassic, thalasophyte, the sea.
a member of group of plants which, although diverse in physiology, reproductive methods, structure and size, shows limited differentiation to definite organs. An alga, bacterium, or fungus.
as in thalloid, thallophyte, prothallus, a young shoot (in usage meaning an undifferentiated structure).
compound of a thallus.
a vegetative body undifferentiated to a root-shoot system.
as in thalpophilous, warmth.
as in calothamnus, a shrub.
as in theca, thecal, thecate, microtheca, a case.
(plural thecae) in general, a protective covering structure, e.g. a capsule or sporangium. Thecial: relative to a theca.
as in thelymitra, female.
as in thermal, thermograph, thermometer, heat.

suffixes denoting for plants a tolerance to a particular temperature range, e.g. stenotherm, stenothermy, a plant adapted to, and the ability to live within, a very limited range of temperature; microthermic, adapted to conditions of the cold temperate zone; mesothermic, adapted to temperate (moderate heat) conditions; megathermic, adapted to moist heat (of the tropics).
the effects of differences in temperature during the photoperiod (q.v.).
tolerating high levels of heat, as certain bacteria and blue-green algae (thermophytes).
as in therophyllous, summer (hence developing and holding leaves only during the growing season).
with growth-cycle completed within a single growth season, the plant (an annual) passing the dormant season as seed.
as in thigmotropic, touch.
responsive to the stimulus of contact, as a tendril when contacting a suitable surface.
as in thiophilic, sulphur (hence adapted to high levels of sulphur).
a much-reduced shoot occurring as a flattened sharp structure, or a tip of a shoot when hardened and sharp-pointed.
hair. See also trich-.
see Pin and Thrum-eyed.
as in thryptomene, diminished, inpoverished.

as in thuyoides, of Thuja (Cupressaceae). The associated thujona of Boronia (Rutaceae) is taken from a principal constituent of its essential oil, thujone, originally isolated from Thuja. From Gk. thyon, a sacrifice.
as in thymifolia, of Thymus (Labiatae). From Gk. thuo, to perfume.
a paniculate inflorescence with a determinate main axis and indeterminate lateral axes, the whole forming a compact pyramidal cluster. From Gk. thyrsos, a wand.
as in thysanotus, fringed.
of a grass, a branch developed from a bud at the base of the stem. Tillering: the production of such a branch.
of soil, the physical status in relation to plant growth. Usually refers to structure q.v.) after tilling or cultivation.
a shredded material; down; hock.
the limit of tree-growth in sub-alpine and alpine regions, or (as in dry timber line) the lower limit on mountains in arid regions where rainfall decreases with decrease in altitude.
dye-producing; used in dyeing.
as in tiphophyte, a pond or pool.

an aggregation of cells from the same origin (the tissue then simple) or different origin (the tissue then complex) with a specific function. A fundamental structural unit of an organ. See collenchyma, parenchyma, sclerenchyma, vascular system.
as in tmesipteris, a notch; a fork (hence 'Fork-fern').
as in monotoca, a birth (hence the fruit with a single seed).
as in atomic, microtome, biotomic, dichotomy, a cutting or division.
covered by matted hair (tomentum).
as in hypotonic, hypertonic, isotonic, of concentration of a solution.
as in tonoplast, tonotaxis, tension.
the membrane of a vacuole.
of movement when as a response to a change in the density of the containing medium.
as in topography, topodeme, a place.
relative to the general surface-configuration or relief of a geographic region.
see under deme.
in a general sense, the superficial layer of soil down to six or eight inches, approximately the A horizon.
with knob-like, fleshy swellings. From L. torosus, muscular; feshy.
with a twisted collar or ring.
parched; arid.
cylindric but of varying diameter; moniliform.

of a flower, the receptacle.

Of a tracheid, the central thickened part (of two primary walls and a middle lamella) of a membrane of a bordered pit. It is surrounded by a thin, often perforated annulus of an unthickened primary wall and may block the pit when pressure forces it against the border. From L. torus, a swelling. Plural tori.
a poison.
as in toxanthus, a bow.
(plural trabeculae) in general, a row of cells extending across a cavity.

a specialised cell of xylem (both primary and secondary), usually elongate, non-living at maturity, lignified and with secondary-thickened walls strongly pitted. Either a tracheid or vessel, the vessel differing in that its walls are perforated for the ready passage of water and lacks the torus (q.v.) of the bordered pit of the tracheid.
The tracheid is considered the more primitive tracheary element, although not a distinguishing feature since vessels occur throughout most groups of vascular plants. Of angiosperms, the vessel occurs in all families except those considered primitive. See also xylem, vessel.
see Tracheary element.

a vascular plant. A member of those groups generally specialised for autotrophic existence through a division of parts, a development of vascular system, and a life-cycle in which the gamete-forming phase is short.
as in trachymene, trachysperma, rough.

one of the winds which blow from the tropical high-pressure belt towards the equatorial belt of low pressure. In Australia, the main direction is from the south-east (at latitudes 15° to 35°) so that for locations with an easterly aspect the wind brings moisture from the sea, but the inland and interior with a westerly aspect, dry to arid conditions are maintained.
as in tragopogon, a goat.
as in translocation, across; through.
of ecology, a line or strip across a vegetation taken as a sampling of the components.

of the leaves of gymnosperms, a tissue associated with a vascular bundle, usually made up of tracheids and parenchyma or tracheids alone, generally considered to function in the conduction of solutes between the vascular bundle and the mesophyll.

within a plant, the transport of a solute. See vascular system, phloem, xylem.

Of chromosomes, a structural rearrangement in which a segment is translocated to a different position of the same or different chromosome.

light when passing through a transparent or semi-transparent object to a degree determined by the physical nature of the object, e.g. ordinary glass will allow transmission of light at wave-lengths greater than 3,600 A but is opaque to wavelengths less than this. Ultra-violet light thus is not transmitted.

the release of water vapour (evaporation) from a plant to the external atmosphere at a rate dependent initially on the equilibrium existing between the vapour pressure of moisture within the plant and the relative humidity of the surrounding atmosphere. Sunlight promotes the process by increasing the vapour pressure within the plant.

the movement or flow of water and solute through a plant from the region of uptake to the region of transpiration, e.g. the rise of sap. In vascular plants the conduction is through tracheids and vessels of xylem. The process is not yet fully clarified, one concept hypothesising a transpiration-cohesion-tension theory. In brief, transpiration from the surface of leaves creates deficits in the diffusion pressure existing in lower regions which, in consequence, draw on the vascular system for water to equilibrate the deficit. Tension, in turn, is created on the elements of xylem which, in equilibrating turgidity, transmit a downward tension effect through the xylem to the root, the cohesive force of water maintaining an upward flow. Roots also exsert a powerful pressure (e.g. as evidenced by the 'bleeding' of stumps) and may aid in the maintenance of an unbroken water column.
in a cross-wise direction.
a section taken at right-angles to a longitudinal axis.
in the form of a plane figure with four straight sides, no side parallel with another.
as in traumatic, traumatotropic, a wound.
a growth substance generated in a wounded tissue of a plant which, on diffusion to proximal uninjured cells, stimulates their division.
relative to a curvature in growth when effected as a response to a wounding influence.
as in trema, tremelloid, a tremble (hence gelatinous).

the habit of a plant when perennial branches arise from a single woody stem (trunk), i.e. a monopodium. Of angiosperms, is the habit of about ten percent or total species, the habit considered more primitive than the herbaceous type. From Anglo-Saxon treo.
as in treponema, a turn (hence a turning thread).
as in trifid, trimerous, tripartite, three. From L. tres, Gk. treis.

a category at a level below a family (and its sub-unit) and above a genus. A taxonomic group within a family (or sub-family) sharing a relationship among certain of its genera.
The name given to the tribe is taken as a plural adjective used as a substantive, its suffix as recommended by the Code is -eae (-inae for sub-tribe) preferably ending the name of an included genus. e.g. the Podalyrieae of the family Papilionaceae unite such genera as Podalyria, of South Africa, and the Australian Brachysema, Oxylobium, Chorizema, Gompholobium, Daviesia, Pultenaea, Dillwynia etc. partly on the relationship of free stamens.
as in triboloid, a burr (hence burr-like or prickly).
as in tribonanthus, a coarse cloak.
as in triboluminescence, a rubbing (hence luminescence from friction).
a prickly plant.
as in trichoid, trichocarpus, acrotriche, hair. From Gk. thrix.
as in trichinium, hairy.
one of the cells of the epidermis of a root which gives rise to a root-hair.

a general term for an outgrowth from an epidermis, a hair or scale which may be unicellular or multicellular, branched or unbranched, secretory, absorbing, or non-functional.

Of a bacterium or blue-green alga, a flamentous chain of cells enclosed, typically, in a gelatinous sheath.
triangular, three-sided or -angled.
threefold.
trigonal.
of a dull, sad or unattractive appearance.

of a species with flowers of three forms (1) styles long and anthers at two levels below the stigmas (2) styles of intermediate length, one set of anthers above the stigmas, the other set below (3) styles short, anthers at two levels above the stigmas. The heterostylous condition (tristyly) occurs in the families Pontederiaceae, Oxaldidaceae, and Lythraceae.
as in triticum, a rubbing (the Latin name for wheat, derived from an allusion to its grain being rubbed down to make it edible).
as in trochoid, trochocarpus, anthotroche, a wheel.
as in trophic, trophotropic, ectotrophic, hypotrophy, nutrition.
with the tendency to turn towards a nutrient supply.

as in geotropic, phototropism, tropophilous, heliotropium, isotropis, a turning or change in direction.

Sometimes, as in calotropis, a keel.

relative to the region between the two parallels of latitude, the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn roughly 23½°N. and 23½°S. respectively, but often including latitudes a few degrees N. and S. of these parallels.
